answers.answer: Welcome!  Lots to think about. Your dr will know if you're able to take the new triple therapy. It's a weekly injection and 2 other oral meds. The new oral med is what keeps the virus from multiplying as the other 2 drugs team up to wipe it out. I hope you're a candidate for it. Did they give you a MELD score or run any other tests like sonography or endoscopy? Good luck. You can find a ton of good info if you search this site.. Karen ;) keep us posted.

You must be reeling from the double whammy, and though it's for less than happy reasons, welcome to the forum.It's not unusual for folks with hep c to also have diabetes... experts believe that their may be an increased incidence of diabetes in hep c patients.  In regards to your liver biopsy, it should not only measure grade (degree of inflammation) but also stage (amount of fibrosis).  With 'fibrosis, you could be stage 2 or 3... in either case, certainly time to seriously consider treating sooner rather than later.As a diabetic, you should make sure to address that with your treatment doc (hopefully a hepatologist experienced in treating hcv).  Recent literature indicates that it is very important to manage your diabetes to improve your odds of success in hcv treatment... I'm not familiar with the particulars, but there is a considerable amount of information in the archives if you search for "diabetes and hcv", and a number of folks pretty knowledgeable about the diabetes-hcv link... hopefully one of them will chime in.Depending on your genotype of hcv and your particulars, your doctor will recommend a combination of drugs that will include oral and injectable meds (the oral med is Ribavirin, and the injectable[s] is Interferon and one of two other possibilities if your are geno 1 -- geno 2-4 use just Ribavirin and Interferon.  There is also the option of clinical trials which your doctor may or may not recommend that may be worth exploring.You'll probably find that you'll have many questions in the coming days...you might find it helpful to write them down to bring them with you to the visit Tuesday.  I've found it helpful to ask for copies of all test results at every visit so it's available to review at anytime for better understanding.  Good luck moving forward. ~eurekacrossroadsec:They usually don't order sonos, endos, or run MELDs unless you're stage 4.

Take notes on everything dr tells u at the meeting. It will go so fast much info will fly by. And great info on asking and getting all paperwork at each dr visit so you can educate yourself and also track progress good luck :)
